body: I h ave pushed up another commit to this that finishes the implementation of Unordered Sequences, with the exception of one test (test_simple_nil) that seems to cause an infinite loop for some reason.  The unordered sequences in the vCard also work now, athough there are a few other things to clean up in that schema before it is working 100%.

I've just pushed changes that rename the function, and also fixes a integer overflow issue when converting the explicit length long to an int. With that fix, I am able to parse a 3.4GB bmp file. I'm a little concerned we have other places doing an unsafe .toInt call.

I also tested on unparse, and ran into an out of memory error in the BufferedDataOutputStream. I think the issue there is it's backed by a BuferredArray, whcih has a limit of 2GB. We probably need to split buffered data output streams when they reach 2GB. But that's unrelated to the blob feature. I'll create a bug for that.
We can't really claim BLOB works until this unparser buffered output stream bug gets fixed. And definitely no point creating a release until that is fixed.

Well, it does work with blobs smaller than 2GB :) And you could hit this bug using something other than blobs with just 2GB of data. It's not really a blob issue so much as a buffered data limit issue. 

But yeah, this definitely needs to be fixed for 2.5.0--a major use case is for files larger than 2GB which will almost certainly use blobs.

I've created DAFFODIL-2194 to fix the 2GB unparse issue.

> See other comment to fix.
> 
> You should squash what will be 3 commits together and then force-push your changes again. That way it will be one single commit when it hits the master.
> 
> Thanks

@mbeckerle Updated the PR as advised. I will recheck after CI run.

@mbeckerle it looks like for some reason one of the CI phases timed out at Integration test.
Could you help to re-trigger it pls?

Will try again tomorrow. My current attempts to re-try all tests then fail with a git checkout error that makes no sense:
   git checkout --progress --force 77f6143198b29368072669fae0d6fbebb14b6807
   ##[error]fatal: reference is not a tree: 77f6143198b29368072669fae0d6fbebb14b6807

It looks like the GitHub actions CI is failing due to https://github.com/actions/checkout/issues/23. I think we'll just have to rely on TravisCI until this issue is resolved.

Though, it looks like the first part of the bug is still an issue. The ``dfdlx.xsd`` file has the following lines:
```xml
  <xs:import namespace="urn:ogf:dfdl:2013:imp:daffodil.apache.org:2018:int" schemaLocation="xsd/dafint.xsd" />
  <xs:import namespace="http://www.ogf.org/dfdl/dfdl-1.0/" schemaLocation="xsd/DFDL_part3_model.xsd" />
```
The bug report says that the schemaLocation attributes should be this:
```xml
  <xs:import namespace="urn:ogf:dfdl:2013:imp:daffodil.apache.org:2018:int" schemaLocation="dafint.xsd" />
  <xs:import namespace="http://www.ogf.org/dfdl/dfdl-1.0/" schemaLocation="DFDL_part3_model.xsd" />
```
I.e., the "xsd" directory is removed from the schemaLocation. I'd doesn't look like that was fixed as another PR. I *think* the bug is right and the xsd should be removed.

Also, I recommend changing the commit message to remove the squashed commit messge "fixed broken tag" since the squashed commit doesn't actually fix any broken tags. Also, in the Daffodil project, the standard is to list the bug number at the end of the commit message, so your commit message should look something like this:

> xs:import problems with xsd files provided in daffodil-lib
>
> Removed extra whitespace
>
> DAFFODIL-2200
@stevedlawrence thank you for checking this PR. I have addressed review comments in latest commit.

Codecov report indicates you are missing tests that manually throw the fatal and non-fatal exceptions you have defined for intentional explicit use by end-users. I thought I saw tests of those though, so this may be spurious.

Other than that the non-coverage things look to be limitations of the scala compiler. E.g., it seems to always say this line is not covered:

`val Some(x) = y`

probably because it doesn't know that y is always type Some on this code path, so it thinks this assignment can fail possibly, and that failure path is not covered by tests of course, because it actually is not really possible. Rewriting as:

`val x = y.get`

Should remove the coverage red-mark, because the type-check code path is now over in the definition of the get method of the Option type, not here in this code. 

The latter may also generate better/smaller code. Or rather, we know for sure what y.get is going to do, whereas the pattern assignment may or may not (depending on optimizers) contain calls to unapply methods and other artifacts of how pattern destructuring works.

```

DelimiterStackParser                0.308   3.15%      244  1259220
ChoiceParser                        0.226   2.31%     5750    39360

OrderedUnseparatedSequenceParser    0.058   0.60%  2922016       20
ConvertTextCombinatorParser         0.000   0.00%     8825       40
Total Time: 9.783
```
So we can see we spend a third of the time trying to parse delimted Nils, a quarter of the time trying to parse delimited strings, a thenth parsing actual delimiters, and so on. So to get any real benefits, we really just need to focus on speeding up these parsers. Note that this isn't too surpsing, we would expect delimiter scanning to take up a good chunk of the time, but it's helpful to see that in number form.

I figured out the vmf_s2s problem. 
We check path expressions more thoroughly now, and one of the checks is that a path has to always refer to an array, or a non-array, not a mixture of them. vmf_s2s has a use of msi:FRI in a hand-crafted schema for a message. The FRI is not inside an array, but FRI uses a discriminator that refers to fn:count(..) which formula ".." has to refer to an array, and usually does. But in the one handcrafted message schema, ".." refers to a scalar. That mix is no longer allowed. By fixing the handcrafted schema to use FRI in the same idiom it was designed for, the problem goes away.
The 'sbt it:test' failures were spurious. I had JVM out of memory messages in that run also. A second run is clean, and Travis says all is working.

+1 👍 Thanks for the contribution!

Before we merge this, to other Daffodil devs, are there any thoughts on putting a moratorium on merging pull requests during a release vote?

Say this was a large complex change and we merged it during a vote. Then say the vote failed and we needed to make a minor fix (e.g. update LICENSE) and create a new release candidate. The complex change isn't going to have as much testing, and could make the new release candidate less stable. In that case, I think it makes sense to hold off on merging the complex change until after the release is out so that it is slated for the following release.

We could take it on a case by case basis (in this case, I think it would be fine to merge and include in a new release candidate if there happened to be one), but then we need to define what level of complexity is okay which isn't obvious. It might be easier to just define a rule that says no merging during release votes?

Thoughts? This discussion might be more appropriate for the dev list, but I think this is the first PR where this has come up so thought I'd mention it here before we merge.
